Texas Governor Calls Out Travis County Sheriff, Announces State Wide Sanctuary City Ban 
The statement on Travis County revealed that 142 criminally charged illegal immigrants had been released by the city between Jan. 28 and Feb. 3 of this year. That, according to a Department of Homeland Security report , represents nearly 70 percent of the criminally charged illegal immigrants released nationwide. 
The report, according to the statement from the state of Texas, “highlights the counties that are not cooperating with Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) detainer requests. 
“From the time period between January 28 – February 3, 2017, 206 criminally charged illegal immigrants nationwide were released from custody due to the denial of ICE detainer requests. The worst offender was Travis County, which accounted for 142 (nearly 70%) of those released and charged with crimes including sexual assault, aggravated assault, domestic violence, and robbery.” Advertisement - story continues below 
“Today’s report from DHS is deeply disturbing and highlights the urgent need for a statewide sanctuary city ban in Texas,” Abbott said in the statement. 
“The Travis County sheriff’s decision to deny ICE detainer requests and release back into our communities criminals charged with heinous crimes — including sexual offenses against children, domestic violence, and kidnapping — is dangerous and should be criminal in itself. Texas will act to put an end to sanctuary policies that put the lives of our citizens at risk.”
